summary_points: 1. Cognizant Technology Solutions Corporation's Board of Directors approved a $2 billion increase to its existing stock repurchase program on March 24, 2025, bringing the total remaining authorization to approximately $3.1 billion.
2. For 2025, the company increased its share repurchase expectation by $500 million to $1.1 billion.
3.  Cognizant anticipates improved relative revenue performance and margin enhancements in 2025, aiming to "return to the Winner's Circle," although specific numbers weren't provided in this filing.

1. Philip Morris International Inc. (PMI) updated its segment reporting on March 25, 2025, to include remaining Wellness and Healthcare results within the Europe segment and renamed its "PMI Duty Free" business to "PMI Global Travel Retail," resulting in four segments: Europe, SSEA, CIS & MEA, EA, AU & PMI GTR, and Americas.
2.  PMI's total net revenues for the full year ended December 31, 2024, were $38,719 million, a 10.1% increase compared to 2023.

3. Exhibits 99.1 and 99.2, incorporated by reference, provide recast unaudited financial information for 2024 vs 2023 and 2023 vs 2022 respectively,  with  no change to PMI's previously reported consolidated financial position or results of operations.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$652,261,027.88 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of March 24, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2.  On March 24, 2025, 21,324,940 Class A shares and 10,522,944 Class B shares were repurchased, totaling US$432,706,611.73 and US$218,967,539.92 respectively.
3. News Corp intends to continue repurchasing Class A and Class B common stock from time to time, subject to market conditions and other factors.

1. On March 19, 2025, Otis Worldwide Corporation amended its bylaws to revise director nomination procedures, remove limitations on stockholder action by written consent, and eliminate certain director resignation requirements.
2.  The filing does not contain any year-over-year numerical comparisons of financial performance.
3. The amended bylaws, effective March 19, 2025, could potentially impact future shareholder activism and the process of electing directors.
1. Joseph V. Taranto retired as Chair of Everest Group, Ltd.'s Board of Directors, effective after the May 2025 Annual Meeting of Shareholders, with John Graf nominated to succeed him.
2.  Joseph V. Taranto served as Chairman since 1994 and CEO from 1994 to 2013.
3. John Graf, nominated to replace Taranto as Board Chair, has been an independent board member since 2016 and is the Non-Executive Vice Chairman of Global Atlantic Financial Group.
1. On March 23, 2025, Steven J. Moskowitz was terminated as President and CEO of Crown Castle Inc., with Daniel K. Schlanger appointed as Interim President and CEO.

2. Daniel K. Schlanger received a compensation package including a $100,000 monthly stipend and approximately $9.225 million in restricted stock units (RSUs) upon his appointment as Interim President and CEO on March 23, 2025.
3. Crown Castle Inc. expects to close the sale of its Fiber business in the first half of 2026.
1. Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. (CECONY) entered into a new $500 million 364-day revolving credit agreement on March 24, 2025, replacing an expired agreement.
2.  The new credit agreement allows CECONY to borrow up to $500 million, compared to the previous agreement’s unspecified amount.

3.  The agreement includes covenants restricting CECONY’s debt-to-capital ratio to 0.65 to 1 and limiting liens on assets to 10% of consolidated net tangible assets; failure to comply constitutes an event of default.
1. On March 24, 2025, Cintas Corporation terminated discussions to acquire UniFirst Corporation, citing an inability to reach a mutual agreement on key transaction terms.
2.  The proposed acquisition of UniFirst by Cintas was valued at $275.00 per share, representing a 46% premium over UniFirst's ninety-day average closing price as of January 6, 2025.
3. Cintas plans to continue its growth strategy through disciplined mergers and acquisitions and investment in technology.
1. Lowe's net sales decreased by 3.1% year-over-year to $83.7 billion in fiscal year 2024 (ended January 31, 2025).
2.  Lowe's plans to spend approximately $2.5 billion on capital expenditures in fiscal year 2025.
3.  Lowe's CEO plans to sell up to 58,000 shares of company stock by May 29, 2026.
1.  At the Walt Disney Company's annual shareholder meeting on March 20, 2025, a shareholder proposal requesting a report on climate risks to retirement plan beneficiaries failed to pass.
2.  Overwhelming support was shown for the election of Robert A. Iger to the board of directors, with 1,213,662,424 votes in favor compared to only 6,767,376 against.
3. The ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent registered public accountants for fiscal year 2025 passed with 1,374,322,498 votes for and 95,981,468 against.
1. On March 24, 2025, Advanced Micro Devices closed a public offering of $1.5 billion in senior notes, consisting of $875 million in 4.212% notes due 2026 and $625 million in 4.319% notes due 2028.
2.  Also on March 24, 2025, the company issued $950 million in unsecured commercial paper.
3. The company's new debt agreements include covenants limiting the ability to create liens on certain assets, enter into sale and leaseback transactions, and undergo certain mergers or asset sales.
